Legal_Issue: Whether Zhang met the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Zhang was absent from Canada for significant periods due to her husband's employment in Japan
Court_Ruling: Appeal allowed; citizenship judge's decision set aside
Defendant_Behavior: Prolonged absence from Canada during the required four-year period
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency requirement
Assessment_Factor: Family ties outside Canada, passive connections improperly considered
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, family circumstances, employment reasons for travel
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least three years of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and pattern of absences, justification for time spent abroad
Governing_Rule: Applicant must have three years of residence in Canada during the four years preceding application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of actual residence in Canada
Harm_Assessment: Potential undermining of immigration and citizenship integrity
Cause_Description: Minister of Citizenship and Immigration appealed the citizenship judge's decision granting Zhang citizenship
Evidence_Handling: Court found failure to properly assess relevant facts such as family ties abroad
Evidence_Issues: Passive connections given undue weight; lack of focus on physical presence
Evidence_Assessment: Qualitative test for residence not correctly applied
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship judge erred by not properly assessing factual basis for residency claim
Evidentiary_Issues: Reliance on passive connections instead of physical presence
